statement.tex: \text{Differentiate the following function}\\ \text{with respect to x}\\ \quad f(x) = \cos x^3\cdot\sin^2 (x^5)
\\ \textbf{Right or wrong? } \text{If }f(x) = g(x)\cdot h(x)\text{, then }\\ \frac{d}{dx}f(x)\text{ is given by the following.}

reason.tex: \text{When differentiating a function of the}\\ \text{form }f(x) = g(x)\cdot h(x),\text{ use the }\textbf{Product Rule.}\\ \qquad \dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) = h(x)\cdot\frac{d}{dx}g(x) + g(x)\cdot\frac{d}{dx}h(x)

options.tex:
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Function} & \text{Derivative} \\ \hline g(x) = \cos x^3 & -3x^2\cdot\sin x^3 \\ \hline h(x) = \sin^2 (x^5) & 2\sin x^5\cdot\cos x^5\cdot 5x^4 \\ & = 10x^4\cdot\sin x^5\cdot\cos x^5 \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\
\begin{align} &\therefore f'(x) = \cos x^3\dfrac{d}{dx}\sin^2 (x^5) + \sin^2 (x^5)\dfrac{d}{dx}\cos x^3 \\ &= 10x^4\sin x^5\cos x^5\cos x^3-3x^2 \sin x^3 \sin^2 (x^5) \end{align}

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Function} & \text{Derivative} \\ \hline g(x) = \cos x^3 & -\sin x^3 \\ \hline h(x) = \sin^2 (x^5) & 2\sin x^5\cdot\cos x^5 \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\
\begin{align} &\therefore f'(x) = \cos x^3\dfrac{d}{dx}\sin^2 (x^5) + \sin^2 (x^5)\dfrac{d}{dx}\cos x^3 \\ &= \sin x^5\cdot [2\cos x^3\cdot\cos x^5 + \sin x^3\cdot \sin x^5] \end{align}

reason.tex: \text{You need to apply the }\textbf{Chain Rule}\text{ when} \\ \text{differentiating the following} \\ \begin{align} \dfrac{d}{dx}\cos x^3 &= \dfrac{d}{d x^3}\cos x^3\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx} x^3 \\ &= -3x^2\cdot\sin x^3 \\ \dfrac{d}{dx}\sin^2 (x^5) &= \underbrace{\dfrac{d}{d\sin x^5}\sin^2 x^5}_A \cdot\underbrace{\dfrac{d}{d x^5}\sin x^5}_B \cdot\underbrace{\dfrac{d}{dx}x^5}_C \\ &= \underbrace{2\sin x^5}_A \cdot \underbrace{\cos x^5}_B\cdot\underbrace{5x^4}_C \\ &= 10x^4\cdot\sin x^5\cdot\cos x^5 \end{align}
